articles.headline: BP to Pay Record Fine for Refinery
articles.snippet: BP has agreed to pay a record $50.6 million fine for safety violations found last year at its troubled Texas City refinery.
articles.abstract: BP has agreed to pay a record $50.6 million fine for safety violations found last year at its troubled Texas City refinery.
articles.lead_paragraph: BP has agreed to pay a record $50.6 million fine to the federal government for safety violations found by regulators last year at its troubled refinery in Texas City, Tex., where 15 workers died in a 2005 explosion.

articles.headline: Eat an Apple (Doctor’s Orders)
articles.snippet: Some doctors in Massachusetts are handing out coupons for use at farmers’ markets in an effort to promote healthy eating and combat childhood obesity.
articles.abstract: Some doctors in Massachusetts are handing out coupons for use at farmers’ markets in an effort to promote healthy eating and combat childhood obesity.
articles.lead_paragraph: The farm stand is becoming the new apothecary, dispensing apples  not to mention artichokes, asparagus and arugula  to fill a novel kind of prescription.

articles.headline: Taxes No Longer So Certain
articles.snippet: The current unsettled state of the tax code is a threat to the economy, but Congress is unwilling to compromise.
articles.abstract: The current unsettled state of the tax code is a threat to the economy, but Congress is unwilling to compromise.
articles.lead_paragraph: Death may still be certain, but taxes have never been less so.

articles.headline: Indian Forces Face Broader Revolt in Kashmir
articles.snippet: Protests in Kashmir have led India to one of its deepest crises and mark the failure of its efforts to win peace there.
articles.abstract: Protests in Kashmir have led India to one of its deepest crises and mark the failure of its efforts to win peace there.
articles.lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR, Kashmir  Late Sunday night, after six days on life support with a bullet in his brain, Fida Nabi, a 19-year-old high school student, was unhooked from his ventilator at a hospital here.

articles.headline: Dell Accused of Concealing Evidence in PC Suit
articles.snippet: Dell deliberately violated a court order by failing to hand over documents from top executives, a court filing said.
articles.abstract: Dell deliberately violated a court order by failing to hand over documents from top executives, a court filing said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Dell has been accused of withholding evidence, including e-mails among its top executives, in a lawsuit over faulty computers it sold to businesses, according to a filing made Thursday.

articles.headline: New G.M. Chief Known as a Pragmatic Leader
articles.snippet: Daniel F. Akerson has a knack for parachuting in, surveying the landscape and making changes.
articles.abstract: Daniel F. Akerson has a knack for parachuting in, surveying the landscape and making changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  For the last year, General Motors has been under the leadership of a former telecommunications executive with no tolerance for indecision or distractions, Edward E. Whitacre Jr.
articles.byline: By Nick Bunkley and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Ruing Exile, Russian Says He’s No Spy
articles.snippet: Igor Sutyagin, plucked from the bowels of a Russian prison camp, was freed last month in a dramatic spy swap, but wants to go home.
articles.abstract: Igor Sutyagin, plucked from the bowels of a Russian prison camp, was freed last month in a dramatic spy swap, but wants to go home.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Call him the spy who wants to go home again. Except that Igor Sutyagin insists he is not a spy. And his friends warn him not to go home again.

articles.headline: Spending Posts Now a Liability for Lawmakers
articles.snippet: Members of Congress who once won voter loyalty for sending money back home are now being punished.
articles.abstract: Members of Congress who once won voter loyalty for sending money back home are now being punished.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Membership on the Appropriations Committee used to be a first-class ticket to Congressional success, guaranteeing lucky lawmakers the ability to campaign on the federal money they had lavished on the folks back home. But the era of the appropriator appears to be on the wane.
